@drcrallen It is actually IndexingServiceClient in the core code that connects the dots between hadoop-indexing and druid-server. If we want to move things to extensions, IndexingServiceClient has to be refactored to be generic enough so that it doesn't depend on CilentXXXQuery.
@drcrallen Regarding handling multiple hadoop versions. I believe it's covered in DruidCoordinatorHadoopMergeConfig where you can specify the hadoop coordinates.

FWIW, DruidServerMetadata should be the source of truth of a Druid node's metadata, if you want to get basic metadata of a Druid node, use DruidServerMetadata. DruidServer actually just means a Druid node that can load segments, i.e. Historical or Realtime. It is constructed from serialized DruidServerMetadata, but it stores more information about the segments it is serving. So technically it should be a subclass of DruidServerMetadata (I am working on refactoring this in #2242). 

If Druid never uses serialized DruidServer,  I am :+1:
It's also fine to leave them as is. I am fine with either.

IMO this patch looks really good especially when the input data is roughly sorted by timestamp, and my machine logs are like that.
Map disk spill is one of major performance bottleneck in MR but combiner does nothing about that.
This patch can reduce the number of spills with minimized map output.
Even it works as best effort, it would be well fit with time series data I think.

after https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1576 goes in I'll update the extension to be able to use the dynamic configuration stuff. I'll see if I can get this fixed at the same time. I agree making it smarter and clearer about the uri is the right way to go.

My suggestion is having 3 fields:

`uri` - An absolute URI to grab data from

XOR

`uriPrefix` - A prefix for doing pattern matching.
`nodeRegex` - An optional regex for matching the node part of the uri path. something like `"channel-lookup[\-0-9]*\.json"` in your example would match any of the following: `channel-lookup.json`, `channel-lookup-0000.json` but NOT include `channel-lookup.json.backup`

from an API perspective I think @drcrallen 's suggestion is the way to go.
@vogievetsky I amended the comment just a bit at the end to clarify regex behavior, just FYI
@du00cs any chance of fixing the merge conflicts and squashing commits?

@guobingkun `io.druid.client.indexing.IndexingServiceClient#runQuery` already just takes an object and passes it down, so the refactoring wouldn't be too heavy.

The heavier part of the refactoring would probably be in `io.druid.server.coordinator.DruidCoordinator#makeIndexingServiceHelpers` which does not have pluggable helper discovery.

Rather than having all the `config.isXXX` checks in there, it make sense to me to have a pluggable method for allowing the dynamic configuration to bring in implementations for helpers without having to have hard-coded sets of available helpers.

such a thing might be outside the scope of this PR though. But doing this PR without fixing the helper plug-ability is increasing technical debt.

My concern with the approach in DruidCoordinator for this PR is it is neither the way things were previously done, nor a more pluggable way which makes clear allowing of extending helpers... which means it is introducing a third way of handling it which will have to eventually be reconciled if/when the debt for pluggable helpers gets paid off.

Can you either:
1. Fix the tech debt for pluggable helpers
2. Make the approach for defining helpers in `makeIndexingServiceHelpers` match the approach used previously so that future paying off of tech debt doesn't have to account for multiple ways of doing things there. (Also file an issue about pluggable helpers)

?
@navis I think it makes sense adding a string utility class to druid to make it easier to do those kinds of changes. A lot of String optimizations in that area are going to be druid specific anyway.

We are evaluating Druid for our use-case and this is the one thing I believe we are lacking. @sandeep217 's example is very similar to our case since our mapping changes fairly regularly, so I would like to :+1: this feature.

Added improvement 6: supervisor no longer kills all tasks on startup, but checks to see if the task matches the supervisor's spec and expected offsets and starts tracking it if it conforms. If it doesn't match, it will kill the task to prevent ingesting duplicate events.

Overall this PR is ready to go IMO. there is minor comments to be fixed, :+1:

have finished reviewing this PR - 
two comments - 
1) there are places where namespace and lookup are used interchangeably, minor places like variable names, package names needs to be changed 
2) In the initialization the user is required to manually init with an empty lookup, which can be avoided, but not a blocker for PR and can be added in a github issue and done in a separate PR. 

I am :+1: on this and think this can be merged once 1 is taken care of unless @b-slim has any more comments.

That looks great. Thanks for the benchmarks too!

So this PR is not dependent on the "dim types" patch you mentioned? I could theoretically apply it to druid 0.8.2? (Not sure if I actually will, we're tentatively planning to upgrade to 0.9.0 when it's released - did this make it in time for that release?)

Timeout is set twice. if I'm understanding the javadocs correctly the init() setting is for simply establishing a connection, while the setting in the call is for the request/response of that specific request.

Anyways, looks good :+1:

This breaks backwards compatibility and will break our deployments. Instead of completely foregoing the prior methodology of using ClassLoader resources, would it be possible to have a property that contains a list of files to use to create Properties, in ADDITION to pulling from the ClassLoader mechanism as was previously done?
revised a little. would it better to have single `druid/config` path in classpath rather than adding  `druid/config/_common:druid/config/$SERVER/`?

Performance:
Sketch query

```
{
  "queryType":"timeseries",
  "dataSource":"someDataSource",
  "granularity":"day",
  "intervals":["2016-03-06T00:00:00/2016-03-06T23:59:59"],
  "aggregations":[
    {
      "fieldName":"visitor_id_sketch",
      "name":"uv",
      "type":"thetaSketch"
    }
  ],
  "context" :  {
    "useCache":"false",
    "populateCache":"false"
  }
}
```

Take time:

```
real    0m3.286s
user    0m0.001s
sys 0m0.002s
```

DistinctCount query:
Use java bitmap

```
{
  "queryType":"timeseries",
  "dataSource":"someDataSource",
  "granularity":"day",
  "intervals":["2016-03-06T00:00:00/2016-03-06T23:59:59"],
  "aggregations":[
    {
      "fieldName":"visitor_id",
      "name":"uv",
      "bitmap": {"type" : "java"},
      "type":"distinctCount"
    }
  ],
  "context" :  {
    "useCache":"false",
    "populateCache":"false"
  }
}
```

Take time:

```
real    0m0.973s
user    0m0.001s
sys 0m0.002s
```

DistinctCount query:
Use roaring bitmap
"bitmap": {"type" : "roaring"},
Take time:

```
real    0m2.348s
user    0m0.001s
sys 0m0.002s
```

DistinctCount query:
Use concise bitmap
"bitmap": {"type" : "concise"},
Take time:

```
real    3m40.176s
user    0m0.000s
sys 0m0.003s
```

@dclim nice write up. here are the things, i think, we need to have in the order of priority.

I believe number (3) is a MUST have . Supervisor must persist its state in metadata store because overlord going down or changing leadership is a very common case, even in case of rolling deployment.

(5) about  early stopping of tasks and related "user supplies number of events a task will handle", it is very difficult for users to figure out that number and many times it could change depending on hour of the day, day of the week. This might impact rolling deployment also where some tasks are never finishing.

(2) about remaining replica's showing FAILED status is confusing to users. It will require users to very carefully look at the overlord console task statuses to say whether ingestion is working fine or if there are genuine failures.

@navis that is how we deploy it internally, with a single config path in the classpath that contains both runtime.properties and common.runtime.properties (and log4j2.xml and other stuff)

For the example deployment I think it makes things clearer if there is clear delineation between the node types.

Are these documented?
it's timeBoundary (the very first query the test does).  query to the broker is ok, same query to the router times out.
modified class is used by RouterJettyServerInitializer
modified docs, @drcrallen thanks for pointing it out.
@rasahner not sure I understand what you mean by "modified class is used by RouterJettyServerInitializer"

AsyncQueryForwardingServlet was modified by PR https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2674.
In RouterJettyServerInitializer:
       final AsyncQueryForwardingServlet asyncQueryForwardingServlet = new AsyncQueryForwardingServlet( ....)

I don't see how the PR would cause different query behavior, but our build based on the druid.io master branch failed when the only change from the previous build was this PR.  I think the router is trying to do something using http (contact a broker?) and can't make a connection.
@rasahner is it possible that #2644 introduced this issue?

I don't think that is likely.  Our builds (incuding runs of all IT tests) passed after that PR was merged.  Also, I think that PR would only have an affect after the query was being processed.  In this failure, the query seems to be running into trouble at the router (doesn't seem to get to a broker).

Yes, QTL is undergoing a lot of improvements in the near future, and proper handling of applyAll and unapplyAll is among them.

In the mean time, have you tried offHeap caching for the existing lookups? that should help reduce heap memory pressure.

We are looking to do something similar here, however we have 2 ECS clusters of historical nodes.  Would it also be possible to load the same segments with the same priority on the historical servers across two tiers?  In effect this creates two replicas of the data that you round robin to correct?
